Name: Process vs Thread Basics
Key Points / Tips: Difference in memory & context: processes have separate memory, threads share process memory; threads are lighter for concurrency

Name: CPU Scheduling (FCFS/SJF/RR/etc)
Key Points / Tips: Know how First-Come-First-Serve, Shortest Job First, Round Robin, etc. work and their pros/cons (FCFS can starve long jobs, RR adds time quantum etc.)

Name: Synchronization & Critical Sections
Key Points / Tips: Multiple threads/processes need mutual exclusion to avoid race conditions; protect critical sections using locks (mutex/semaphore)

Name: Semaphore vs Mutex Difference
Key Points / Tips: **Semaphore**: signaling mechanism (can allow multiple threads); **Mutex**: locking mechanism (exclusive, with owner). Mutex is binary semaphore with ownership and stricter access

Name: Deadlocks (Conditions & Prevention)
Key Points / Tips: Deadlock requires 4 Coffman conditions (mutual exclusion, hold & wait, no preemption, circular wait). Prevention/avoidance: break one condition (e.g. use resource ordering)

Name: Banker's Algorithm (Deadlock Avoidance)
Key Points / Tips: Resource-allocation algorithm to avoid deadlock by checking for a safe state before allocating. Understand safety sequence check

Name: Virtual Memory & Paging
Key Points / Tips: Use disk as “virtual” extension of RAM. Paging divides memory into fixed-size pages/frames to load only needed pages. Know page table concept and addressing

Name: Page Replacement Algorithms
Key Points / Tips: When page fault and memory full: FIFO, LRU, Optimal algorithms decide which page to swap out. Know Belady’s anomaly (FIFO) and that LRU approximates optimal

Name: Paging vs Segmentation
Key Points / Tips: Paging: fixed-size pages, no external fragmentation. Segmentation: variable segments, fits logical divisions but can cause external fragmentation

Name: Memory Fragmentation (Internal/External)
Key Points / Tips: **Internal**: wasted space inside fixed partitions/pages (process smaller than block). **External**: free memory is split into small holes over time

Name: User Mode vs Kernel Mode (System Calls)
Key Points / Tips: OS runs in **kernel mode** (full HW access), user apps in **user mode** (limited). Switching via system calls/traps to perform privileged operations

Name: File Systems & Inodes
Key Points / Tips: Inode is metadata structure storing file attributes and disk block pointers (in UNIX). Understand how files are organized (directories, FAT vs NTFS concepts)

Name: Disk Scheduling Algorithms
Key Points / Tips: Disk head scheduling: e.g. FCFS, SSTF, SCAN (elevator), C-SCAN. Know that SSTF can starve far cylinders, SCAN reduces seek time by back-and-forth sweep

Name: Dining Philosophers Problem
Key Points / Tips: Five philosophers share 5 chopsticks – illustrates need for avoiding deadlock (e.g. using odd/even resource ordering or a semaphore for max 4 philosophers eating)

Name: Producer-Consumer (Bounded Buffer)
Key Points / Tips: One producer, one consumer share fixed buffer. Use synchronization (mutex for buffer access + two semaphores: “empty” and “full”) to avoid overflow/underflow

Name: Thrashing (Excessive Paging)
Key Points / Tips: Thrashing = CPU spending more time swapping pages in/out than executing. Caused by working set too large for RAM. Mitigation: working set model or increase RAM
